abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Judicial Reform Support
            Project for Philippines were as follows: outcomes were
            unsatisfactory; risk to development outcome was high; Bank
            performance was moderately unsatisfactory and borrower
            performance was unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned
            includes: judicial reform, including this project, enjoyed
            this type of strong support during the first three years of
            this project but less so in the subsequent years. The waning
            of senior Court management support twenty five (and indeed
            from the Court as a whole) for the reforms as envisaged at
            the start of the project, reduced attainment of the
            project's development outcomes. Protracted procurement
            procedures and time-consuming management processes requiring
            heavy involvement by senior officials can undermine reform
            momentum and project results. Project design could build in
            'circuit breakers' to allow disengagement during
            project implementation if certain key assumptions are not
            fulfilled, or unforeseen events occur. Whenever focus moves
            from results and implementing agencies shift focus from
            outcomes to process, reform momentum wanes. Care is needed
            to ensure that a dedicated Program Management Office (PMO)
            is well-equipped and supported throughout the project life,
            and that it works effectively with the judiciary's key
            operating institutions twenty six, in supporting and
            coordinating reforms, rather than succumbing to time-driven
            pressures and becoming directly involved in implementing reforms.

14772619.trustfund:
TF039870-PHILIPPINES-JUDICIAL REFORM,TF040603-PHILIPPINES INSOLVENCY LAW,TF026102-PHRD-JUDICIAL REFORM PROJECT,TF037862-PHILIPPINES - JUDICIAL REFORM,TF050807-PHRD-PHILIPPINES: JUDICIAL
            REFORM SUPPORT PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
Philippines - Judicial Reform Support
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Judicial Reform Support Project for Philippines is to
            support an accessible judicial system that would foster
            public trust, and confidence. For the financing of a total
            project cost of US$24.4 million, the International Bank of
            Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) loan comprises US$21.9
            million and the government contribution US$2.5 million. The
            project could not be completed by the original closing date
            of December 31, 2009, and the closing date was extended by
            18 months, to June 30, 2011. However, this extended period
            has not been sufficient to complete the project, due to (i)
            limited implementation and coordination capacity in the
            implementing agency; (ii) lengthy procurement processes;
            (iii) changes in the judiciary leadership (although the pace
            of implementation has picked up under Chief Justice Renato
            Corona's leadership  more than $1.3 million has
            disbursed in the first half of calendar 2011 alone) and (iv)
            the very severe 2009 tropical storm Ondoy which set back
            implementation into early 2010 due to damage to courts and
            records. The modifications comprise (i) a one-year extension
            of the closing date from June 30, 2011 to June 30, 2012,
            (ii) reallocation of loan proceeds, (iii) cancellation of an
            amount of US$0.5 million from the loan proceeds, and (iv)
            dated covenants for cancellation, at the Bank's
            discretion, of activities and associated loan proceeds if
            agreed implementation milestones are not met. There are no
            changes to components but there are modifications to some
            activities within components, as indicated in the
            procurement-cum-implementation plan. These changes have no
            implications for the development objectives. The allocations
            for contracts to be entered into during the extension period
            are summarized below these are in line with agreed priorities.

display_title.display_title:
Philippines - Judicial Reform
            Support Project : restructuring  : Main report

14493862.trustfund:
TF026102-PHRD-JUDICIAL REFORM PROJECT,TF037862-PHILIPPINES - JUDICIAL REFORM,TF039870-PHILIPPINES-JUDICIAL REFORM,TF040603-PHILIPPINES INSOLVENCY LAW,TF050807-PHRD-PHILIPPINES: JUDICIAL

repnme.cdata!:
Philippines - Judicial Reform Support
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Judicial Reform Support Project for Philippines is to
            support an accessible judicial system that will foster
            public trust, and confidence. Negative impacts include: air
            quality, noise, traffic, waste generation, and aesthetics.
            Mitigation measures include: 1) proper housekeeping shall be
            implemented, and regular sprinkling of ground particularly
            during arid days; 2) proper provision of collection, and
            proper handling and storage of construction materials; 3)
            noise generating equipment shall be provided with mufflers,
            proper maintenance of equipment; 4) equipment utilization
            shall be scheduled, work hours shall likewise be schedule
            during daytime only; 5) reusable materials shall be salvaged
            for future related projects, others shall be sold or given
            to workers; 6) domestic wastes shall be collected and
            disposed off with the municipal collection system; 7)
            vehicles/trucks delivering construction materials shall be
            regulated; 8) project's design concept that caters to
            nature shall be considered to further enhance the aesthetic;
            and 9) proper maintenance of vehicles shall be encouraged.

display_title.display_title:
Philippines - Judicial Reform
            Support Project : environmental assessment  (Vol. 2) :
            environmental management and monitoring plan

            nature shall be considered to further enhance the aesthetic;
            and 9) proper maintenance of vehicles shall be encouraged.
